user.biography:
Author of UNTAMED and LOVE WARRIOR
Host of WE CAN DO HARD THINGS Podcast
Founder of @together.rising

node.text:
.
On today’s We Can Do Hard Things podcast, I share my best advice for how to communicate with highly-sensitive, upset kiddos. And, in this moment in which everything feels so awful, so overwhelming, so hard, I think it may be helpful for us to use with ourselves, too.  

So, here’s what we are going to do when those big, hard feelings come—for us, or for our little ones:

We aren’t going to try to fix those feelings. We are going to stop trying to fix, and instead start meeting them exactly where they are. All we have to do is make them feel seen. Instead of explaining away, minimizing, or rationalizing—we will AGREE with them that this thing that is happening is the worst thing that has ever happened and that they have every right to be devastated. 

(It works for me only every single time.)

In this week’s second episode of We Can Do Hard Things, @AbbyWambach, Amanda, and I continue talking about talking: 

1️⃣ Amanda has a Ted Lasso moment, presenting a case for “summer rain” love—and rejecting “lightning love” as the highest form of romantic love. 
2️⃣ I offer ideas about how to know when to speak up or shut up.
3️⃣ Abby shares her experience in a mostly-male meeting that proved “silent solidarity” is a cowardly lie. 

Listen at the link in my bio.
G

node.text:
.
When I go out into the world, it feels like everyone is talking and nobody is listening to each other ever. It feels like most “conversations” are just endless cycles of people interrupting each other, one-upping each other, waiting to talk without listening, or creating monologue hostage situations. It feels like such a WASTE.

Conversation is the tool we have to connect—to feel less alone. But nobody really teaches us how to use our tool. I think that could be why we're so lonely: Because we don't even really know how to use the one tool we have to connect with each other.  

So, today, on We Can Do Hard Things, @AbbyWambach, Amanda, and I are talking about talking—and how we can begin to use conversation as a key to unlocking each other. 

*Interrupting is my Conversation Pet Peeve. It takes my anxiety through the roof. I know some of you disagree completely: What feels destructive to me feels constructive and creative to you. 

WHAT’S YOUR CONVERSATION PET PEEVE?

WHAT MAKES YOU FEEL MOST CONNECTED AND HEARD IN CONVERSATIONS?

WHO DO YOU LOVE TO TALK TO THE MOST? WHY?

Listen at the link in my bio. 
G

node.text:
.
This week on the We Can Do Hard Things pod, @AbbyWambach, Amanda, and I are discussing how culture’s invention of gender is the lens through which the world sees and reacts to us, including Amanda’s observation:

“I'm very direct, confident, assertive, and effective in my job roles. In other words, if I were a man, I would be what you would call a very successful businessman. But since I am not a man, even though I lead us in attaining really good business results, I am constantly being labeled as a lot or difficult to work with or aggressive.”

We also discuss:
1️⃣ Abby’s experiences of being publicly misgendered—and how that makes her feel.
2️⃣ Why is gender the last place we’ve agreed it’s acceptable to make identity assumptions?
3️⃣ Why do we tell people who they are before they’re even born—and a thousand different ways every day after?
4️⃣ Why Glennon says two women in a marriage, handling their own business, rocks the patriarchal boat. 

How do gender assumptions affect how people see you and react to you?

Listen at the link in my bio.

Love,
G

node.text:
.
Today on We Can Do Hard Things, we’re going to get to know Amanda a little better. 

Some people like to roller skate for fun. Amanda likes studying gender and power dynamics. As you’re listening to this conversation, you’ll understand that all of the themes that we explore in the podcast, in @Together.Rising’s work, and in UNTAMED—themes of women and power structures—have always been informed by my sister’s knowledge and passion. 

She is the lens that helps us see: We are not crazy. We’re cheetahs the world has tried to cage.

I love my sister, Amanda. And I’m so happy you do, too.

Listen at the link in my bio.
G

P.S. She’s also really freaking funny. In this clip, we consider: WHY IS IT THAT HALF THE POPULATION LOOKS AT THEIR FACES AND THINKS “I’M GOOD” AND THE OTHER HALF LOOKS AT OUR FACES AND THINKS “NOT GOOD ENOUGH.”

node.text:
.
We can do hard things. But do we need to do them ALL THE TIME?

In today’s episode, we try easier.  We talk about:
1️⃣ My radical acceptance that I’m always going to be a midnight person in a sunshine world.
2️⃣ Our favorite movies and music—and what they reveal about our personalities.
3️⃣ Why @abbywambach is objectively hot, but please don’t tell me that at parties.

Listen at the link in my bio.

node.text:
.
Today, on We Can Do Hard Things, we’re discussing the power of quitting as an act of self-love, freedom, and survival. 

We recorded this episode before Simone Biles stepped away from an Olympic moment to protect her own mental, physical, and emotional health. Judging by the world’s reaction to her NO heard ‘round the world—we think we were onto something with this convo. Because the world loses its damn mind when a woman, especially a Black woman, decides to abandon the world's expectations of her instead of abandoning herself.

In this conversation, I go toe-to-toe with two of the biggest non-quitters I know: Abby Wambach and my sister, Amanda Doyle. 

We discuss how to know when it’s time to let something or someone go. Perhaps we have to ask: Do I want to become free of this thing because this thing is hard for me—or do I want to become free of this thing because it’s NOT for me?

We can quit hard things! Let’s go!

Listen at the link in my bio.

node.text:
.
If you’ve listened to our Tuesday episode of We Can Do Hard Things, you understand why it was so important to me to Untame my sex life. I want us all to begin to experience sex as a place where we please and honor ourselves, not just our partners. When we do that, sex becomes real.
 
Today, we answer your Sexy Qs, Say Farewell to Faking It, and Vouch for Vibrators. 
 
Also: Amanda talks through how 75% of women can better set themselves up for success in the bedroom; we discuss detoxing from religious purity / sex shame culture; raising kids with a healthier relationship to sex; and the one sex subject that’s a hard no for Abby and me.
 
Listen at the link in my bio.

node.text:
.
On today’s episode of We Can Do Hard Things, Abby, Amanda, and I ARE TALKING ABOUT SEX, BABY:

1️⃣ Our sex origin stories and how they shape our current sex fears.
2️⃣ My high-pressure situation of sex with Abby for the first time—and how it didn’t go quite as you’d expect.
3️⃣ The biggest sex challenges in our marriages now.
4️⃣ What Amanda regrets about her past sex life—and how she’s already worried about what she’s going to regret when she’s eighty.
5️⃣ How Pod Squaders taught us about “lesbian deathbed.”**

You asked for this episode. I may have sweated my way through every second of it, but we can do hard things. Here we go!

Listen at the link in my bio. There’s a link to transcripts there, too.

** P.S. Apparently the term is actually "lesbian bed death" but perhaps we should reconsider since I think our wording may be more accurate?

node.text:
.
In our first Thursday episode of We Can Do Hard Things—available right now—we’re discussing how Amanda and I are just Pendulum Parenting: overcorrecting the way our parents parented us. Is the result just messing our kids up in the equal and opposite direction?

We’re also talking about my new experiment of combating my hermit tendency by Saying Yes to anything the universe invites me to. I’m tired already.

Please listen at the link in my bio!

And please make sure that you FOLLOW We Can Do Hard Things wherever you listen to podcasts, so you never miss an episode! 

And please leave a review if you love our podcast. But if you hate it, forget I asked.

We’ve also been working hard to make our show as accessible as possible. Find the episode TRANSCRIPTS at the link in my bio after each show.

Okay, Loves, it’s almost Friday—we’ve got this.
G

node.text:
.
We worry so much about our kids thinking we’re perfect, that everything’s perfect—never letting them see our mistakes and pain, never letting them see us try and fall and get back up again. But maybe we should. Maybe our most pressing duty as parents is not to model how to be perfect but how to be HUMAN: how to be brave and kind and how to carry on and forgive each other, and how to try, try, try again to build our truest, most beautiful life. 

Telling the kids that Craig and I were divorcing was the hardest day of my life. Craig and I talk about that hardest day, the complicated decision to get married in the first place, and how we eventually introduced Abby to the kids, in this episode of We Can Do Hard Things. 
Listen at the link in my bio.

Thanks for listening to the podcast, and thank you for welcoming and loving Craig so beautifully.

node.text:
.
Craig’s on today’s episode of We Can Do Hard Things! Listen at the link in my bio.

Our family moved across the country recently from Florida all the way to California. And in the weeks before our move, people kept asking me, Wait, is Craig coming with you?!?!

This question always jarred me completely. I'd say, of course Craig is coming with us. Craig IS us. We'd just as soon move across the country without Amma as without Craig. Craig is my family. My family just looks different than people told me it should. 

I came across this idea long ago that has stuck with me: The thing that screws us up most is the picture in our head of how things are supposed to be.

Craig is joining us today to discuss how we let go of what family “should be” to embrace the family we have. We are going there. We are talking about it all including: 

1️⃣ Craig’s first two thoughts the moment I sent him “the text.”
2️⃣ How Glennon and Craig told the kids they were divorcing. 
3️⃣ The big mistake Glennon and Craig agree they made in the early days of blending their family.
4️⃣ What Craig says is the most annoying thing about co-parenting with Glennon, and the best thing about co-parenting with Abby.
5️⃣ How Craig really feels about Glennon writing their stories. 

Listen at the link in my bio.

node.text:
.
Since the world tells us in a thousand different ways that our bodies are broken, wrong, out of control, and less-than, it’s important to have someone remind us that it’s our world that’s crazy: We're not crazy, we're goddamn cheetahs. 

That someone for me is usually my sister. Here's Amanda’s gentle reminder from this week’s episode about why BMI is horseshit. 

We can do hard things. Like learn to wage peace with our bodies in a world that insists we be at war with ourselves. Listen at the link in my bio.

node.text:
“Turns out, the memo 'A good Christian bases her faith on disapproving of gays and abortion’ started being issued only 40 years ago. In the 1970s, a few rich, powerful, white, (outwardly) straight men got worried about losing their right to continue racially segregating their private Christian schools and maintaining their tax-exempt status. They felt their money and power being threatened by the civil rights movement. In order to regain control, they needed to identify an issue that would be emotional and galvanizing enough to unite and politically activate their evangelical followers for the first time. 

They decided to focus on abortion. Before then—a full 6 years after the Roe v. Wade decision—the prevailing evangelical position was that life began with the baby’s first breath, at birth. Most evangelical leaders had been indifferent to the Court’s decision in Roe, and some were cited as supporting the ruling. Not anymore. They wrote a new memo using freshly feigned outrage and rhetoric calling for “a holy war… to lead the nation back to the moral stance that made America great.” 

They sponsored a meeting of 15,000 pastors— called The Religious Roundtable—to train pastors on how to convince their congregations to vote for antichoice, antigay candidates. This is how they disseminated the memo down to evangelical ministers, and down to pews across America. The memo read: To be aligned with Jesus, to have family values, to be moral, one must be against abortion and gay people and vote for the candidate that is antiabortion and antigay. 

Ronald Reagan-who, as governor of California had signed into law one of the most liberal abortion laws in the country-began using language from the new memo. Evangelicals threw their weight behind him and voted in a bloc for the first time to elect him President. The Religious Right was born. The face of the movement was the ‘pro-life and pro-family values’ stance of millions, but the blood running through the movement’s veins was the racism and greed of a few.”
-Untamed

“Your Body is a Battleground” 
-Barbara Kruger, Untitled, created for the 1989 Women's March on Washington supporting a woman's right to reproductive justice

node.text:
.
When I go out into the world, it feels like everyone is talking and nobody is listening to each other ever. It feels like most “conversations” are just endless cycles of people interrupting each other, one-upping each other, waiting to talk without listening, or creating monologue hostage situations. It feels like such a WASTE.

Conversation is the tool we have to connect—to feel less alone. But nobody really teaches us how to use our tool. I think that could be why we're so lonely: Because we don't even really know how to use the one tool we have to connect with each other.  

So, today, on We Can Do Hard Things, @AbbyWambach, Amanda, and I are talking about talking—and how we can begin to use conversation as a key to unlocking each other. 

*Interrupting is my Conversation Pet Peeve. It takes my anxiety through the roof. I know some of you disagree completely: What feels destructive to me feels constructive and creative to you. 

WHAT’S YOUR CONVERSATION PET PEEVE?

WHAT MAKES YOU FEEL MOST CONNECTED AND HEARD IN CONVERSATIONS?

WHO DO YOU LOVE TO TALK TO THE MOST? WHY?

Listen at the link in my bio. 
G

node.text:
Today, we are making an initial $200,000 commitment to meet the most urgent needs of families impacted by Hurricane Ida. Every penny is being urgently deployed thanks to TEAM LOVE—our amazing recurring monthly donors to @together.rising —whose continuous support allows us to respond as soon as crises strike.

Yesterday, on the 16th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, Hurricane Ida hit landfall in Louisiana. A category 4 storm wielding 150 MPH winds, Hurricane Ida, together with September’s Hurricane Laura, is the strongest hurricane to hit Louisiana's shores in over 160 years.

When Hurricane Laura struck last year, @together.rising immediately deployed help and we’ve remained committed since then. Just two months ago, we invested another $102,000 in our long-time partner to continue to support Louisiana families as they rebuild. To date, our investment has provided vital assistance to 146 families. We have just begun. 

Our boots are already on the ground in Louisiana, still there fulfilling the commitment we made to families after Hurricane Laura. There we will remain. Because the impact Ida has already had on families—many of whom had only just begun to rebuild after Laura—is absolutely devastating.

To every family impacted by Ida, know that all of us in this @together.rising community will continue to stand with you—now through our initial $200,000 commitment and in the months to come. You are not alone. Our hearts are with you and our help is on the way.

If you would like to join us in supporting Louisiana families—you can do so at the link in bio or TogetherRising.org/Give. If you are not in a position to donate but still want to support this effort, please consider sharing this post with your people.

In Unwavering Solidarity and Relentless Hope,
@together.rising

node.text:
.
Language. I am obsessed with it. For many obvious reasons.
 
Language reveals all our conditioning—what we believe and who we are. Today, I’m letting loose with some feelings about gendered insults. This is misogyny Inception, people. 

I believe in the catharsis of cursing. Please enjoy.
(But please also don’t listen with little ones around.)
 
Listen at the link in my bio to this one with Amanda, @AbbyWambach, and me.
 
G

node.text:
.
This week on the We Can Do Hard Things pod, @AbbyWambach, Amanda, and I are discussing how culture’s invention of gender is the lens through which the world sees and reacts to us, including Amanda’s observation:

“I'm very direct, confident, assertive, and effective in my job roles. In other words, if I were a man, I would be what you would call a very successful businessman. But since I am not a man, even though I lead us in attaining really good business results, I am constantly being labeled as a lot or difficult to work with or aggressive.”

We also discuss:
1️⃣ Abby’s experiences of being publicly misgendered—and how that makes her feel.
2️⃣ Why is gender the last place we’ve agreed it’s acceptable to make identity assumptions?
3️⃣ Why do we tell people who they are before they’re even born—and a thousand different ways every day after?
4️⃣ Why Glennon says two women in a marriage, handling their own business, rocks the patriarchal boat. 

How do gender assumptions affect how people see you and react to you?

Listen at the link in my bio.

Love,
G

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Glennon Doyle on August 21, 2021. May be a Twitter screenshot of text that says 'Glennon Doyle @GlennonDoyle Hi. There is a family next to me at the store. just heard the dad say to his kid: 'Well, it's brave to go on a roller coaster. And it's also brave to say you don't want to go roller coaster." Wanted to tell you something good. That is good. on a'.

node.text:
Because: 
Brave is matching your insides and outsides.
If one wants to ride and does, that's brave.
If one does not want to ride and doesn't- that's brave.
Actions are not inherently brave- the honoring of the inner compass instead of the outer expectation is the braveness. 
Brave cannot be judged by the crowd. Sometimes we are the only one who knows we've been brave. 
And that is enough. 
That is everything.

#GetUntamed

*y'all the dude didn't say all this. This is my added commentary and largely from Untamed. I'm imagining some of you commenters imagining this dad offering this to his kid in the grocery line like the sermon on the mount.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Glennon Doyle on August 20, 2021 tagging @together.rising. May be an image of text that says 'We are standing with the people of Afghanistan. Together Rising has made a $250,000 initial commitment-funds that are on the ground right now helping to bring thousands of women, children, and families to safety. 100% of every penny we receive for Afghanistan will be deployed to trusted partners to meet the most urgent needs now-and in the months to come. TogetherRising.org/Give TOGETHER RISING'.

node.text:
Thousands of Afghan women, children, and families are risking their lives in desperate attempts to evacuate—and through @together.rising you are helping bring them to safety through a $250,000 investment that is already on the ground.

We watched in horror with the rest of the world as the Taliban took Afghanistan, knowing the unimaginable terror and persecution their control guarantees, especially for Afghan women. Immediately, we knew that we would not allow for those women—or their children or their families—to be abandoned. That you would not allow it, either. As we shared on Tuesday, our team has been working diligently to vet the most effective ways for us to invest given the volatile and complex nature of this devastating crisis.

Today, Together Rising made a $250,000 initial commitment—funds that are on the ground helping to bring thousands of women, children, and families to safety. We’ve entrusted this investment to the Afghan women-led team of advocates at @WomenforAfghanWomen, who are working 24/7 in Kabul. They told us that Together Rising’s investment “means Women for Afghan Women (WAW) can continue this critical effort on the ground to provide emergency services . . . because we must. Afghan women, children, and their families are depending on us.” 

The urgency of this crisis is undeniable—but we know that refugees and internally displaced people will need support far beyond the news cycle’s moving on. We will not allow them to be forgotten then, either. That’s why 100% of every penny we receive for Afghanistan will be directed to meet the most urgent needs now—and in the months to come.

Can you help us amplify our response by making a donation through @together.rising to Afghanistan at the link in bio or in @together.rising’s bio? Together, we can help ensure these families will be remembered and continue to be held close by this community.

We owe our deepest gratitude to our recurring donors as your continuous support is what allows us to deploy funds as soon as crises strike. If you are a recurring donor, please say so in the comments so we can thank you personally for the way you showed up this week both in Haiti and Afghanistan.

.
Today on We Can Do Hard Things, we’re going to get to know Amanda a little better. 

Some people like to roller skate for fun. Amanda likes studying gender and power dynamics. As you’re listening to this conversation, you’ll understand that all of the themes that we explore in the podcast, in @Together.Rising’s work, and in UNTAMED—themes of women and power structures—have always been informed by my sister’s knowledge and passion. 

She is the lens that helps us see: We are not crazy. We’re cheetahs the world has tried to cage.

I love my sister, Amanda. And I’m so happy you do, too.

Listen at the link in my bio.
G

P.S. She’s also really freaking funny. In this clip, we consider: WHY IS IT THAT HALF THE POPULATION LOOKS AT THEIR FACES AND THINKS “I’M GOOD” AND THE OTHER HALF LOOKS AT OUR FACES AND THINKS “NOT GOOD ENOUGH.”
